title: Can String Theory be confirmed? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, since it hasn’t been falsified by experiments yet, but things aren’t looking particularly good at the moment. String theory is a model that attempts to describe reality. It remains to be seen if it actually does it. The problem is that it does not provide us with any falsifiable predictions at the moment, but it has some qualities that give it potential, such as the fact that the graviton (the particle-carrier of the gravitational force) unpredictably popped out of the theory. String theory has not been falsified yet. To be falsified, a theorist must find a way to predict something through string theory that other theories that we hold dear at the moment do not and the prediction has to be testable, i.e. it has to be such that we can conduct experiments that are within our technological reach in order to falsify the theory or give it a much needed win. There have been some predictions that are made only by string theory, although we are not able to test them at the moment. In any way, I think that any physicist who has learned string theory will agree that, at least as a mathematical model, it is elegant, sophisticated and it has also provided us with powerful tools that will help us in our quest to describe various phenomena in nature. The grandest example of one such tool is the AdS/CFT correspondence (or gauge/gravity duality). One can read the following very brief article on its usefulness: After almost 20 years of AdS-CFT, what have we learned? Now back to string theory, as a theory that describes our world, it has some serious problems but all incomplete theories have these. One such problem is that it needs Supersymmetry and we didn’t find any evidence for its existence in recent experiments conducted at the LHC in CERN. I believe that the consensus even among people working on string theory is that it is far from being complete and it has gone through and will continue going through a rough ride. To conclude, for me the correct answer is that you can’t write string theory off, but you can’t be very confident about it describing our world. It has already been useful to us but maybe we should start viewing it as a pretty great tool rather than a model describing reality (i.e. being the quantum gravity theory). P.S. For the non-physicists: there are more models, like Loop Quantum Gravity, that can’t be written off. They have their own serious problems but on certainly should not read things only about string theory..!

This opinion comes from a person not so familiar with the theory, yet… No, it can’t be true. Simply speaking, the main elements of this set of theories are chosen wrongly — dimensions and hypothetical strings are very abstract and physically “expensive” terms to play with, that’s not how a universe works, but something way simpler. To my understanding of it, the initial intention behind these theories was to reuse a mathematical formalism of general relativity extended to even more dimensions (as partially demonstrated in Kaluza–Klein theory), while having rules of quantum mechanics included. Various elementary particles should have been quantum-mechanical vibrations of these strings or whatever. So, is it a good recipe for a successful theory ? No, simply no — the approach is too simplified, pretty much blindly reusing theories we don’t understand (sorry, I am not aware of a more politically correct term to say this). The concept of dimensions (all alone strings) is highly abstract and applicable only in a limited range of scales. Notice also here that applying a certain set of formally developed mathematical tools (tensors or whatever applied to a continuum) inevitably and automatically constrains the theory ! If you start with linear spaces and differential equations (pretty much everywhere in contemporary physics), you have already made a hard decision on how your physical model might behave and what its physical interpretation might be. Despite all being said and unsaid here, is it possible that such a theory might “catch” something ? Unlikely, except approximately at some scales. Simply, it’s a wrong type of space trying to describe another kind. For example, try to describe a discrete space in terms of geometry — the relation is somewhat similar here.

First, physical theories are never proven. They're confirmed by experiments. We do not know whether string theory can be experimentally confirmed or not. The issue is that string theory is (possibly) the theory at the shortest distance scale. There is a property of physical theories known as decoupling, which says that as a function of distance, the effects of short distance physics behave asδOO∝(ℓshortℓO)NδOO∝(ℓshortℓO)Nwhere O is some observable and lshortlshort is the short distance scale and lOlO is the distance scale associated with the observable and N is some power that is strict >=0. Frequently N=2 or 4 -- which means that if lstringlstring is 10^18 GeV and l_O = 1000 GeV (LHC observations), we're talking about immeasurable small discrepancy. There are a classes of observables where N=0. This is obviously good, but you must come up with processes where _only_ string theory contributes to the observable. So far we don't know of any. Finally, the cosmic microwave background radiation can have imprints from inflation, which if the BICEP-2 results are correct, took place at a distance scale that is only a factor of 100 or so from the string scale. This is one of the excitement about the BICEP-2 result -- it would indicate the shortest distance scale probe of physics that we will ever have.
